title: fanoutqa: Who are the current government leaders of the top four countries in terms of GDP? (70da494f6dbf575c)

chat_history.content: Who are the current government leaders of the top four countries in terms of GDP?
I'll help you search for information about the leaders of the top 4 countries by GDP (United States, China, Japan, and Germany). Let me search for each country's leadership.

359. **^** Harrison, David (October 23, 2023). "The Economy Was Supposed to Slow by Now. Instead It's Revving Up". *The Wall Street Journal*. Recent economic data suggest the economy is accelerating despite higher borrowing costs, the resumption of student-loan payments, and wars in Ukraine and the Middle East ... Analysts, many of whom had expected a recession this year, are pushing up their forecasts ... After predicting a recession for the past year, economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal this month said they now believe that the economy will avoid a downturn in the next 12 months.
360. **^** Cathey, Libby (March 13, 2023). "Amid crisis, Biden tells Americans 'banking system is safe'". *ABC News*. Retrieved March 13, 2023.

</fragment>

352. **^** Liptak, Kevin; Mattingly, Phil (January 28, 2022). "Biden is aiming to hit the road to reset his presidency. He starts with yet another stop in Pennsylvania". CNN. Archived from the original on February 4, 2022. Retrieved February 1, 2022.
353. **^** "President Biden Job Approval". *RealClearPolitics*. Archived from the original on January 24, 2021. Retrieved February 10, 2022.
354. **^** Daniel, Will (July 18, 2022). "Inflation drives President Biden's economic approval rating to a record low". *Fortune*. Retrieved September 13, 2022.
355. **^** Bhattarai, Abha (January 26, 2023). "U.S. economy grew 2.1 percent in 2022, but recession fears linger". *The Washington Post*.
356. **^** Jesse Pound; Samantha Subin (December 30, 2022). "Stocks fall to end Wall Street's worst year since 2008, S&P 500 finishes 2022 down nearly 20%". CNBC.
357. **^** Iacurci, Greg (January 12, 2023). "Here's the inflation breakdown for December 2022 — in one chart". CNBC.

<fragment>
China's economy has grown under Xi, with GDP in nominal terms more than doubling from $8.53 trillion in 2012 to $17.73 trillion in 2021,[171] while China's nominal GDP per capita surpassed the world average in 2021,[172] though the rate of growth has slowed from 7.9% in 2012 to 6% in 2019.[173] Xi has stressed the importance of "high-quality growth" rather than "inflated growth".[174] He has additionally stated that China will focus on quality of economic growth and that it has abandoned a growth-at-all-costs strategy which Xi refers to as "GDP heroism".[175]: 22 Instead, Xi said that other social issues such as environmental protection are important.[175]: 22 His administration pursued a debt-deleveraging campaign, seeking to slow and cut the unsustainable amount of debt China has accrued during its economic growth.[176] Though China's total non-financial-sector debt-to-GDP ratio reached a record 270.9% by 2020 during the COVID-19 crisis,

In 2017, *The Economist* named him the most powerful person in the world.[489] In 2018, *Forbes* ranked him as the most powerful and influential person in the world, replacing Russian President Vladimir Putin, who had been ranked so for five consecutive years.[490] Since 2013, Reporters Without Borders, an international non-profit and non-governmental organization with the stated aim of safeguarding the right to freedom of information, included Xi among the list of press freedom predators.[491]

**Paramount Leader of the People's Republic of China** 
* **←** Hu Jintao
* (*Current holder*)
 |
|  |


**Xi Jinping** (Chinese: 习近平; pinyin: *Xí Jìnpíng*, pronounced [ɕǐ tɕîn.pʰǐŋ];[a] born 15 June 1953) is a Chinese politician who has been serving as the general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and chairman of the Central Military Commission (CMC), and thus as the paramount leader of China, since 2012. Xi has also served as the president of the People's Republic of China (PRC) since 2013. He belongs to the fifth generation of Chinese leadership.

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Based on the search results, let me provide you with key information about Xi Jinping:

Xi Jinping is the current paramount leader of China, holding several key positions:
1. General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) since 2012
2. Chairman of the Central Military Commission (CMC) since 2012
3. President of the People's Republic of China (PRC) since 2013

Some notable points about his leadership:

1. Power and Influence:
- In 2017, The Economist named him the most powerful person in the world
- In 2018, Forbes ranked him as the most powerful and influential person in the world, replacing Russian President Vladimir Putin

2. Economic Impact:
- Under Xi's leadership, China's economy has grown significantly
- China's GDP in nominal terms more than doubled from $8.53 trillion in 2012 to $17.73 trillion in 2021
- He has emphasized "high-quality growth" over "growth-at-all-costs," which he refers to as "GDP heroism"
- His administration has pursued debt-deleveraging campaigns

3. Term Limits:
- In 2018, term limits on the presidency were removed
- He has been reelected as General Secretary in 2017 and 2022

4. International Perception:
- According to polls, he has mixed reception internationally
- A 2021 Politico and Morning Consult poll found that among Americans:
  - 5% had a favorable opinion
  - 38% had an unfavorable opinion
  - 17% had no opinion
  - 40% had never heard of him

5. Press Freedom:
- Since 2013, Reporters Without Borders has included Xi among their list of press freedom predators

Xi Jinping was born on June 15, 1953, and belongs to the fifth generation of Chinese leadership. He has consolidated significant power in China and is often considered the most powerful Chinese leader since Mao Zedong.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.
